text: A hydrophobic domain of <extra_id_0> Ca2+-modulating cyclophilin ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> modulates calcium influx signaling in T lymphocytes .

<extra_id_0> Ca2+-modulating cyclophilin ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CAML <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) was originally described as a <extra_id_0> cyclophilin B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding protein whose overexpression in T cells causes a rise in intracellular calcium , thus activating transcription factors responsible for the early immune response .

text: As reported here , structure - function analysis of the <extra_id_0> CAML <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene in Jurkat T cells indicates that two of <extra_id_0> CAML <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> 's putative membrane-spanning domains are necessary and sufficient for the modulation of intracellular calcium .

We propose that the hydrophobic C-terminal tail of <extra_id_0> CAML <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> forms its effector domain , thus implicating the N-terminal hydrophilic domain in a regulatory role .
These findings define a novel protein motif that functions in intracellular calcium signaling .
